Articles: {"abstract": "NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 12 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ \u2014 Johnson & Johnson today voluntarily disclosed to the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that subsidiaries outside the United States are believed to have made improper payments in connection with the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries. The actions were contrary to the Company's policies, and the payments may fall within the jurisdiction of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. The Company will provide additional information to DOJ and SEC, and will cooperate with the agencies' reviews of these matters.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/12/business/12jandjstatement.ready.html", "snippet": "", "lead_paragraph": "NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 12 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ \u2014 Johnson & Johnson today voluntarily disclosed to the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that subsidiaries outside the United States are believed to have made improper payments in connection with the sale of medical devices in two small-market countries. The actions were contrary to the Company's policies, and the payments may fall within the jurisdiction of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act. Icahn, the investor, agreed to buy most of Trump Entertainment Resorts\u2019 bank debt, pitting Mr. Icahn against a bondholders\u2019 reorganization plan for the casino operator. Mr. Icahn leads a group that will buy a secured loan from the Beal Bank, which is first in line among creditors, and agreed to back the lender\u2019s reorganization plan for Trump Entertainment, according to a statement Friday. Trump Entertainment\u2019s three casinos filed for bankruptcy protection for the third time in February, blaming a high debt load and falling revenue. The founder, Donald Trump, and his daughter, Ivanka, dropped Beal as a partner last month and backed a bondholder plan that would give him up to 10 percent of the reorganized company. {"abstract": "Suppose it is 2011 and the so-called Volcker Act has become law, curtailing banks\u2019 riskier activities, like hedge funds and proprietary trading.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/25/business/25views.html", "snippet": "Suppose it is 2011 and the so-called Volcker Act has become law, curtailing banks\u2019 riskier activities, like hedge funds and proprietary trading.", "lead_paragraph": "Suppose it is 2011 and the so-called Volcker Act has recently become law, sharply curtailing banks\u2019 riskier activities, like hedge funds and proprietary trading, and separating those activities from consumer businesses and retail deposits. Citigroup\u2019s recently arrived chief executive, Bob Steel, formerly of Wachovia, is dismantling the group to comply with the law. A memo to the bank\u2019s staff announces that Tim Geithner has been hired as head of the bank\u2019s strategy and investor relations. Oddly, this imaginary situation is not such a stretch. ", "lead_paragraph": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Leaders of the Senate Banking Committee said Tuesday that they had reached an agreement to limit the likelihood that big banks would be bailed out by taxpayers. {"abstract": "An overhaul of the financial regulatory system will vastly expand governmental authority in a bid to curb what led to the plunge of the world economy in 2008. {"abstract": "Its recent cancellation of the Kin smartphone adds to a long list of product misfires \u2014 from watches to music players \u2014 that have plagued Microsoft\u2019s consumer division.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/05/technology/05soft.html", "snippet": "Its recent cancellation of the Kin smartphone adds to a long list of product misfires \u2014 from watches to music players \u2014 that have plagued Microsoft\u2019s consumer division.", "lead_paragraph": " Microsoft\u2019s engineers and executives spent two years creating a new line of smartphones with playful names that sounded like creatures straight out of \u201cThe Cat in the Hat\u201d \u0097 Kin One and Kin Two. Childs Associates and BAML Capital Partners, the latest large leveraged buyout in which a company would pass from one private equity group to another. The deal values Advantage at about $1.8 billion, according to a person close to the deal who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss it publicly. Apax will acquire about 85 percent of the company, with Advantage\u2019s existing management owning the rest. Advantage, based in Irvine, Calif., is a leading sales and marketing agency for consumer goods, working with clients like J. M. Smucker and Johnson & Johnson to maximize the value of their brands. The company has about $1 billion in annual revenue and is expected to generate about $180 million in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization this year, according to this person. J. W. Childs and BAML Capital Partners, formerly Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity, acquired the closely held Advantage in 2006 for $1.05 billion. The firms are expected to make roughly three times their cash investment on the deal, which is expected to close by year-end. {"abstract": "Mylan, a generic-drug maker, agreed to pay $65 million to settle a lawsuit by the federal and Texas governments asserting that the company had inflated prescription drug prices.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/25/business/25bizbriefs-MYLANTOPAY65_BRF.html", "snippet": "Mylan, a generic-drug maker, agreed to pay $65 million to settle a lawsuit by the federal and Texas governments asserting that the company had inflated prescription drug prices.", "lead_paragraph": " Mylan, a generic-drug maker, agreed to pay $65 million to settle a lawsuit by the federal and Texas governments asserting that the company had inflated prescription drug prices, increasing the cost of reimbursing pharmacies and other providers. The company admitted no wrongdoing in agreeing to the payment. Since 2003, Mylan has been sued by 18 states making similar allegations, according to the company\u2019s 2009 annual report. Last year, Mylan, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson agreed to pay $124 million to settle claims they violated laws by underpaying Medicaid rebates, the Justice Department said. {"abstract": "Johnson & Johnson said Friday that the president of its DePuy Orthopaedics division, a maker of artificial hips and knees that has struggled with product recalls and lawsuits, is leaving the company.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/05/business/05bizbriefs-JOHNSONJOHNS_BRF.html", "snippet": "Johnson & Johnson said Friday that the president of its DePuy Orthopaedics division, a maker of artificial hips and knees that has struggled with product recalls and lawsuits, is leaving the company.", "lead_paragraph": "Johnson & Johnson said Friday that the worldwide president of its DePuy Orthopaedics division, a maker of artificial hips and knees that has struggled with product recalls and lawsuits over faulty implants, is leaving the company. The executive, David Floyd, submitted his resignation last week and will leave at the end of March, a spokeswoman said. He had been president of the unit since 2007. He is leaving to pursue interests outside the company, the spokesman, Lorie Gawreluk, said, declining to be more specific. DePuy recalled the ASR XL Acetabular hip system last August, after researchers found 13 percent of patients needed a repeat operation to fix problems with the implant. The company took a $280 million charge in the fourth quarter to pay for the recall. The company faces more than 500 lawsuits by patients who had the hip implants. ", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Johnson & Johnson Implant Unit Executive Resigns", "kicker": "Business Briefing | HEALTH CARE", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Johnson & Johnson Implant Unit Executive Resigns", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "Johnson & Johnson", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-03-05T02:56:24+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Bloomberg News", "person": [{"firstname": "Bloomberg", "middlename": null, "lastname": "News", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/fac7df27-e4d2-5958-8c15-7cc8e4599a6d", "word_count": 141, "uri": "nyt://article/fac7df27-e4d2-5958-8c15-7cc8e4599a6d"}

{"abstract": "Closing the Cordis division in the face of dwindling market share, the company expects to trim 900 to 1,000 jobs this year.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/16/health/16stent.html", "snippet": "Closing the Cordis division in the face of dwindling market share, the company expects to trim 900 to 1,000 jobs this year.", "lead_paragraph": "Johnson & Johnson announced on Wednesday that it would stop manufacturing drug-coated heart stents by the end of the year, abandoning an intensely competitive $4 billion market after a series of setbacks for the company and rising concerns about the use of stents in some patients.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Johnson & Johnson to End Line of Drug-Coated Heart Stents", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Johnson & Johnson to End Line of Drug-Coated Heart Stents", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Medical Devices", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Johnson & Johnson", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Stents (Medical Devices)", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2011-06-15T19:48:32+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Health", "byline": {"original": "By Duff Wilson", "person": [{"firstname": "Duff", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Wilson", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/52033430-34e6-55e0-aaa3-19baa38d3896", "word_count": 588, "uri": "nyt://article/52033430-34e6-55e0-aaa3-19baa38d3896"}

{"abstract": "Basic economics dictates that fiscal responsibility does not require banning deficits.", "web_url": "https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/07/07/the-trouble-with-balanced-budgets/", "snippet": "Basic economics dictates that fiscal responsibility does not require banning deficits.", "lead_paragraph": "I realize they may just be practicing politics, but Senators Olympia Snowe and Jim DeMint serve up a basic misunderstanding of economics in their commentary on The Wall Street Journal\u2019s op-ed page today. {"abstract": "The $20 billion fund created by BP to pay damages from the 2010 spill in the Gulf of Mexico has halted payments until the judge overseeing the federal court litigation clarifies a recent order.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/04/business/energy-environment/louisiana-bp-cleanup-payments-on-hold.html", "snippet": "The $20 billion fund created by BP to pay damages from the 2010 spill in the Gulf of Mexico has halted payments until the judge overseeing the federal court litigation clarifies a recent order.", "lead_paragraph": "The $20 billion fund created by BP to pay damages from the 2010 spill in the Gulf of Mexico has stopped making payments until the judge overseeing the sprawling federal court litigation clarifies a recent order. Judge Carl J. Barbier in New Orleans ruled on Dec. 29 that settlements reached since Nov. 7 must provide 6 percent of the \u201cgross settlement amount\u201d to an escrow account for certain litigation expenses of plaintiffs\u2019 lawyers. In a letter to Judge Barbier, David Pitofsky, the lead counsel for the fund, asked the judge whether, among other questions, his ruling means that people who have already received money should be forced to give some of it back. \u201cWe feel compelled by the court\u2019s order to freeze payments to eligible claimants until we get clarification from the court,\u201d said Kenneth R. Feinberg, administrator of the fund. ", "print_section": "A", "print_page": "16", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Louisiana: BP Cleanup Payments on Hold", "kicker": "National Briefing | South", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Louisiana: Bp Cleanup Payments Halted", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "BP Plc", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Feinberg, Kenneth R", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Suits and Litigation", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Barbier, Carl J", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-01-04T02:01:16+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "National", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Energy & Environment ", "byline": {"original": "By John Schwartz", "person": [{"firstname": "John", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Schwartz", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Brief", "_id": "nyt://article/70d03e98-fe19-5564-9e3e-0c43fb231a90", "word_count": 143, "uri": "nyt://article/70d03e98-fe19-5564-9e3e-0c43fb231a90"}

"nyt://article/b3370318-f5f7-526a-ad85-75c769495b6f"}, {"abstract": "The text of an internal corporate e-mail on the F.D.A.\u2019s decision not to approve a hip device made by a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary, and a company statement on Tuesday in response to questions.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/22/business/document-2009-e-mail-on-hip-device.html", "snippet": "The text of an internal corporate e-mail on the F.D.A.\u2019s decision not to approve a hip device made by a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary, and a company statement on Tuesday in response to questions.", "lead_paragraph": "In August 2009, the Food and Drug Administration notified DePuy Orthopaedics, a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary, through a \u201cnon-approvable\u201d letter that it had turned down its application to sell a version of a hip device called the A.S.R. in the United States. On Aug. 21, Pamela Plouhar, vice president for worldwide clinical affairs at DePuy, sent the following e-mail to three company executives \u2014 including David Floyd, then DePuy\u2019s president \u2014 reporting the F.D.A. action and its implications. The disclosures in the e-mail contrast with statements made in recent years by the company, which continued to market the device in Europe (and a related model in the United States) before announcing a recall in 2010. Here is the text of the e-mail, followed by a statement issued by DePuy on Tuesday in response to questions from The New York Times.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Document: 2009 E-Mail on Hip Device", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Document: 2009 E-Mail on Hip Device", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "organizations", "value": "DePuy Orthopaedics", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Food and Drug Administration", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Medical Devices", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Johnson & Johnson", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Recalls and Bans of Products", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2012-02-22T02:00:28+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "", "person": [], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "Text", "_id": "nyt://article/e48a298e-8a76-524d-9e08-c3021edbf74d", "word_count": 994, "uri": "nyt://article/e48a298e-8a76-524d-9e08-c3021edbf74d"}, {"abstract": "Johnson & Johnson has submitted concessions to the European Union in an effort to complete its $21.3 billion takeover of the Swiss-American medical tools maker Synthes.", "web_url": "https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2012/02/22/j-j-offers-concessions-to-win-approval-for-synthes-deal/", "snippet": "Johnson & Johnson has submitted concessions to the European Union in an effort to complete its $21.3 billion takeover of the Swiss-American medical tools maker Synthes.", "lead_paragraph": "LONDON \u2014 Johnson & Johnson has submitted concessions to the European Union in an effort to complete its $21.3 billion takeover of the Swiss-American medical tools maker Synthes.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "J.&J. {"abstract": "A new campaign for Dramamine is directed at summer vacationers, focusing not on the suffering but on beautiful views from cars, planes and ships.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/21/business/media/new-dramamine-ads-take-aim-at-summer-vacationers.html", "snippet": "A new campaign for Dramamine is directed at summer vacationers, focusing not on the suffering but on beautiful views from cars, planes and ships.", "lead_paragraph": "FOR a product that treats motion sickness, Dramamine has itself barely moved in terms of marketing in recent years, with no national advertising campaigns since at least 2005, according to Prestige Brands, which purchased Dramamine from Johnson & Johnson last year. {"abstract": "Mr. Manning covered the final term of President Franklin D. I\u2019ve worked on the last 14 issues of the Sports Illustrated swimsuit issue, and I\u2019ve been very fortunate to see most of the world. I generally fly in business class, but occasionally coach. In my life outside of work, I seem to always fly coach. {"abstract": "The health care giant reported earnings of $3.8 billion in the second quarter, aided in part by the sale of the company\u2019s stake in Elan of Ireland.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/07/17/business/johnson-johnson-profit-rises-on-strong-prescription-sales.html", "snippet": "The health care giant reported earnings of $3.8 billion in the second quarter, aided in part by the sale of the company\u2019s stake in Elan of Ireland.", "lead_paragraph": "Johnson & Johnson reported on Tuesday that its earnings more than doubled in the second quarter of this year, buoyed by strong sales of prescription drugs and an influx of cash from the sale of its stake in the Irish drug manufacturer Elan.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "2", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Johnson & Johnson Profit Rises on Strong Prescription Sales", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Strong Sales Underpin Earnings At J.&J.", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Company Reports", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Thomas, Katie", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Johnson & Johnson", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Elan Corporation PLC", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-07-16T22:22:54+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "byline": {"original": "By Katie Thomas", "person": [{"firstname": "Katie", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Thomas", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/e7e672da-281b-59b7-806e-16577e7a65f9", "word_count": 252, "uri": "nyt://article/e7e672da-281b-59b7-806e-16577e7a65f9"}

{"abstract": "Given Donald Trump\u2019s financial achievements, and lack of modesty, it is no surprise he opened a school to pass on the secrets of his success, but Trump University always seemed "lead_paragraph": "Leave it to the real estate mogul Donald Trump to give the for-profit education industry an even worse rap than it already has. {"abstract": "Sponsorship spending for cause marketing is expected to total $1.78 billion this year, up almost 5 percent over last year.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/09/30/business/media/accounts-and-people-of-note-in-the-advertising-industry.html", "snippet": "Sponsorship spending for cause marketing is expected to total $1.78 billion this year, up almost 5 percent over last year.", "lead_paragraph": "Sponsorship spending for cause marketing is expected to total $1.78 billion this year, according to IEG, Chicago, up 4.8 percent from $1.7 billion last year. By comparison, spending last year rose only 1.2 percent from 2011. The most active companies sponsoring causes \u2013 as determined by the percentage of causes reporting the companies as sponsors \u2013 are Bank of America, 18 percent; Coca-Cola, 14 percent; and three tied at 13 percent: Wells Fargo, Johnson & Johnson and Wal-Mart Stores.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry", "kicker": "Webdenda", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "ADVERTISING AND MARKETING", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Hiring and Promotion", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Public Relations and Publicity", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Appointments and Executive Changes", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2013-09-30T13:32:10+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Media", "byline": {"original": "By The New York Times", "person": [], "organization": "The New York Times"}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/38906395-26b5-57d1-ad53-3b0dbb65ea9d", "word_count": 742, "uri": "nyt://article/38906395-26b5-57d1-ad53-3b0dbb65ea9d"}

{"abstract": "S.E.C. tribunals are  likely to become busier under the Dodd-Frank law, but some legal experts see a  potential for bias because the judges operate within the agency bringing the cases.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/06/business/at-the-sec-a-question-of-home-court-edge.html", "snippet": "S.E.C. tribunals are  likely to become busier under the Dodd-Frank law, but some legal experts see a  potential for bias because the judges operate within the agency bringing the cases.", "lead_paragraph": "SINCE Mary Jo White settled in as chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, lots of tough talk has emanated from the agency about enforcement priorities. {"abstract": "Excerpts from some columns by Robert J. Shiller, one of this year\u2019s Nobel laureates in economic science, has been a regular contributor to the Sunday Business section of The New York Times. {"abstract": "Excerpts from profiles of the Nobel laureate in 2001, 2005 and 2009 shed light on the path to his professional calling and on his early insights into the post-millennium housing bubble.", "web_url": "https://economix.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/10/15/glimpses-of-shiller-through-the-years/", "snippet": "Excerpts from profiles of the Nobel laureate in 2001, 2005 and 2009 shed light on the path to his professional calling and on his early insights into the post-millennium housing bubble.", "lead_paragraph": "Robert Shiller struggled mightily to choose a major when he was a college student at the University of Michigan in the 1960s. {"abstract": "Mr. Foster, the former vice president of public relations at Johnson & Johnson, helped formulate the company\u2019s response to the multiple deaths related to cyanide-laced capsules of Tylenol.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/30/business/lawrence-g-foster-dies-at-88-helped-lead-tylenol-out-of-cyanide-crisis.html", "snippet": "Mr. Foster, the former vice president of public relations at Johnson & Johnson, helped formulate the company\u2019s response to the multiple deaths related to cyanide-laced capsules of Tylenol.", "lead_paragraph": "Lawrence G. Foster, a former journalist who started the public relations department at Johnson & Johnson and helped lead the company out of a crisis when seven people died after taking Tylenol, the company\u2019s signature pain reliever, died on Oct. 17 at his home in Westfield, N.J. {"abstract": "At one point, $50 billion in federal loan guarantees were meant to cover nuclear projects, but a plant in Georgia may receive the only guarantees made.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/19/business/energy-environment/loan-program-for-reactors-is-fizzling.html", "snippet": "At one point, $50 billion in federal loan guarantees were meant to cover nuclear projects, but a plant in Georgia may receive the only guarantees made.", "lead_paragraph": "WASHINGTON \u2014 Energy Secretary Ernest Moniz is set to announce on Wednesday that he will finish a $6.5 billion loan guarantee this week and another soon for $1.8 billion to help three Georgia electric companies build the first new nuclear reactors in the United States in three decades.", "print_section": "B", "print_page": "3", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Loan Program for Reactors Is Fizzling", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Loan Program for Reactors Is Fizzling", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Federal Aid (US)", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Nuclear Energy", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Energy Department", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "glocations", "value": "Georgia", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Moniz, Ernest J", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-02-19T01:41:17+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Energy & Environment ", "byline": {"original": "By Matthew L. {"abstract": "A number of companies are offering plans that effectively allow companies to reimburse employees for the individual insurance they buy. The problem is that the Internal Revenue Service may not approve \u2014 and the penalties could be big.", "web_url": "https://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/06/04/would-you-try-this-health-insurance-strategy-with-your-company/", "snippet": "A number of companies are offering plans that effectively allow companies to reimburse employees for the individual insurance they buy. The problem is that the Internal Revenue Service may not approve \u2014 and the penalties could be big.", "lead_paragraph": "In March, we interviewed Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel, a doctor who advised the Obama administration on the Affordable Care Act. Dr. Emanuel had just published a book in which he predicted that within a decade, private employers would largely abandon providing health insurance to employees. This, he said, would happen even though such coverage benefits from a big tax break.", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Would You Try This Health Insurance Strategy With Your Company?", "kicker": "You're the Boss", "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "subject", "value": "Health Insurance and Managed Care", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Small Business", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Emanuel, Ezekiel J", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2014-06-04T15:43:35+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "Business", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Entrepreneurship", "byline": {"original": "By Robb Mandelbaum", "person": [{"firstname": "Robb", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Mandelbaum", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/15111eaf-cde3-5424-96ba-5f5cc0ce1001", "word_count": 431, "uri": "nyt://article/15111eaf-cde3-5424-96ba-5f5cc0ce1001"}

{"abstract": "Facing about 1,000 complaints and a yearslong government investigation, G.M. has not recalled 1.8 million trucks with a brake line corrosion problem.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/08/automobiles/gm-resists-recalling-trucks-over-brake-line-problem.html", "snippet": "Facing about 1,000 complaints and a yearslong government investigation, G.M. has not recalled 1.8 million trucks with a brake line corrosion problem.", "lead_paragraph": "Under pressure from federal regulators and legislators, General Motors this year has been reviewing past safety problems. That has resulted in 54 recalls affecting about 25.7 million vehicles in the United States. {"abstract": "Tasmania, with its huge poppy crop, is the top producer of a crucial raw material in prescription drugs. But companies fear that they depend too much on that harvest.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/20/business/international/tasmania-big-supplier-to-drug-companies-faces-changes.html", "snippet": "Tasmania, with its huge poppy crop, is the top producer of a crucial raw material in prescription drugs. But companies fear that they depend too much on that harvest.", "lead_paragraph": "Now is the sowing season for opium poppies in the Australian state of Tasmania. {"abstract": "Wealthy art collectors are benefiting from tax breaks when they build museums with limited public access, often near their homes.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/11/business/art-collectors-gain-tax-benefits-from-private-museums.html", "snippet": "Wealthy art collectors are benefiting from tax breaks when they build museums with limited public access, often near their homes.", "lead_paragraph": "The Brant Foundation Art Study Center \u2014 a picturesque gallery space inside a converted 1902 stone barn \u2014 is just down the road from the Greenwich, Conn., estate of its creator, Peter M. Brant, the newsprint magnate and avid art collector. There are no identifying signs for the center, whether at the turnoff on North Street, at the security gate or on the building itself, though the location is known to the art-world cognoscenti and celebrities who attend the twice-a-year gala openings, held at the private polo club next door that Mr. Brant also founded. Visits to the center itself are by appointment only.", "print_section": "BU", "print_page": "1", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [{"rank": 0, "subtype": "xlarge", "caption": null, {"abstract": "A generation of Indian energy entrepreneurs is out to prove that a fast, clean and economical route to universal electrification is through solar home systems, financed with small bank loans.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/03/business/energy-environment/electrifying-india-with-the-sun-and-small-loans.html", "snippet": "A generation of Indian energy entrepreneurs is out to prove that a fast, clean and economical route to universal electrification is through solar home systems, financed with small bank loans.", "lead_paragraph": "A few years ago, the hundred or so residents of Paradeshappanamatha, a secluded hamlet in the southern Indian state of Karnataka, gathered along the central pathway between their 22 densely clustered homes, and watched as government workers hoisted a solar-powered streetlamp. As the first display of electricity in the town, it was an object of mild interest, but, being outside, the light didn\u2019t help anyone cook or study, and only attracted moths.", "print_section": "BU", "print_page": "1", "source": "The New York Times", "multimedia": [], "headline": {"main": "Electrifying India, With the Sun and Small Loans", "kicker": null, "content_kicker": null, "print_headline": "Electrifying India, With the Sun and Small Loans", "name": null, "seo": null, "sub": null}, "keywords": [{"name": "glocations", "value": "India", "rank": 1, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Bearak, Max", "rank": 2, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Solar Energy", "rank": 3, "major": "N"}, {"name": "subject", "value": "Electric Light and Power", "rank": 4, "major": "N"}, {"name": "organizations", "value": "Solar Electric Light Company (India)", "rank": 5, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Modi, Narendra", "rank": 6, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Hande, Harish (1967- )", "rank": 7, "major": "N"}, {"name": "persons", "value": "Stoner, Robert J (1962- )", "rank": 8, "major": "N"}], "pub_date": "2016-01-02T17:02:26+0000", "document_type": "article", "news_desk": "SundayBusiness", "section_name": "Business Day", "subsection_name": "Energy & Environment ", "byline": {"original": "By Max Bearak", "person": [{"firstname": "Max", "middlename": null, "lastname": "Bearak", "qualifier": null, "title": null, "role": "reported", "organization": "", "rank": 1}], "organization": null}, "type_of_material": "News", "_id": "nyt://article/c522df63-626e-544e-abcd-ec7a30dbd942", "word_count": 2421, "uri": "nyt://article/c522df63-626e-544e-abcd-ec7a30dbd942"}

{"abstract": "Filings in a case against Bayer and Johnson & Johnson over the blood-thinning drug Xarelto said the companies helped mislead editors at The New England Journal of Medicine.", "web_url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/02/business/document-claims-drug-makers-deceived-a-top-medical-journal.html", "snippet": "Filings in a case against Bayer and Johnson & Johnson over the blood-thinning drug Xarelto said the companies helped mislead editors at The New England Journal of Medicine.", "lead_paragraph": "It is a startling accusation, buried in a footnote in a legal briefing filed
